body:
@alerman This issue isn't about the 100 character wrap. That was previously discussed and agreed upon, because it's easier on folks with poor eyesight who need to increase their font size, is a de facto standard by many projects (such as those using Google's Style Guide), and allows for better side-by-side diffs on GitHub and in other diff viewers. Since that was a recent change, it is not likely to be revisited any time soon.

Instead, this issue is more about updating the additional options that have been added to the formatter since Java 8, such as where to wrap lambdas, when to wrap params, and how to wrap array literals, etc. For many of these, we are just using the defaults, because they did not exist last time we examined our style configuration.
@ctubbsii my mistake. I must have misread the linked document with regards to line wrapping. I hadn't thought about the reasons you gave and you definitely convinced me.
@keith-turner Touching base on this. Do you have any opinions on the suggestion in my last comment? Thanks!

For reference, we used to have 160 char line lengths... which was way too long. I think 100-120 is relatively comfortable for me, personally, but Google style guide suggests 80 or 100. 100 was what I proposed. (Here's [the mailing list thread][1].)

[1]: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/bcfcd3891c1586b36317e22200d7cce68cc50431453e2407dc3990cc@%3Cdev.accumulo.apache.org%3E

Should we just reuse the one from [here](https://github.com/google/styleguide/blob/gh-pages/eclipse-java-google-style.xml). Are there other settings you think should be different then googles?

Should we copy this in to our repo, or maybe just sub-tree it so we can get the updates?

I can't remember, but I think the formatter plugin provides that one on the class path already, so we wouldn't even need to copy it in. It doesn't get updated often enough to bother with git subtree or anything like that. I would be happy to use it directly rather than even bother maintaining our own... but it might be worth doing a diff of the two just to make sure that it is what we'd want. I suspect there are some things we'd want to customize, even if it's only a few small tweaks.

I agree this PR does not address point 3 from #517 (I had commented as such on that issue), I felt like removal of that reliance on srv:dir was potentially dangerous, and didnt want to mix concerns in this PR. We could either seperate that out into a seperate issue to be worked after, or we could go forward with this PR but not close 517 until that step is also done. @ctubbsii If you feel it must be part of the same body of work, I will attempt to add that to this PR next week.
I think the `srv:dir` can be addressed separately. I just wanted to make sure we're on the same page about what this PR covers and what it doesn't. :smiley_cat:

After really thinking about it, we can handle most of this in a custom volume chooser without the complexity designed now that the VolumeChooserEnvironment has the endRow. I have stripped the other stuff out.
I still like the Regex endRow chooser that you had... or something like it, but that could go in a separate PR, once this is merged in (which I'll do once I finish running some tests).
Sounds good. I'll submit a new PR with that once it is.
Re-opening to fix broken tests.

I took a quick survey of a few projects : Fluo, Gora, Rya, Geowave, and Datawave and found 3 of 5 are currently using some of these methods.  This change will impact those projects.  What benefit does removing these methods have that justifies the inconvenience for downstream projects? 

>   They should be removed in 2.0 to highlight the newer, better APIs which we support.

Another way to highlight the new APIs is to document them, blog about them, tweet about them, etc...

Major versions are our best opportunities to remove old cruft, and encourage users to migrate to currently supported, APIs that we can continually improve. We have already communicated that these are to be avoided... years ago. If it causes any problems for other projects, I think it will be fine to just provide any support we can to help them migrate their code.
This was fixed in #528

I tested this with [uno] and Hadoop 3.0.2 and it worked fine.

[uno]: https://github.com/apache/fluo-uno

> I tested this with uno and Hadoop 3.0.2 and it worked fine.

Have you tried 3.1.0? Last I heard, 3.1.0 is closer to what they'll call "GA" than 3.0.x
I did not see 3.1.0 on the Hadoop website! I saw 3.0.3 as the latest, but it wouldn't download from Maven, so I dropped back to 3.0.2. I would be happy to try with 3.1.0, though.
Oh, funny. I wonder why that doesn't exist on the website. I didn't think it was a "don't use this" release any more than 3.0.x was...
I found it. It was further down on the list.
3.1.0 seems to have problems with resource utilization on my laptop... I'm not able to get it to run, but I'll try on a beefier machine another time.
What happens if a user tries to use Accumulo 2.0 with Hadoop 2.x?  If there isn't a proper error message currently, I think it would be good to create an issue.

@mikewalch We're not banning the use of Hadoop 2.x... we're just changing the build and testing to expect it by default. It's possible it will still work... if the user deploys it with an appropriate class path (in fact, it definitely still works now). This isn't about forcing users to use a particular version... it's just about what we're focusing our support around.

Similarly, we wouldn't give an error message if a user used log4j 1.2.15, even though we're using 1.2.17; I don't think we should give an error message here, either.

@ctubbsii, sounds good to me. I thought this PR meant Hadoop 2.x would not work in the future. I didn't want users to get weird errors and not know it was due to using Hadoop 2.x. If it "works" but it isn't officially supported, that works for me.

Hey @kpm1985 thanks for the contribution.  Did you try running "mvn clean verify -Psunny"?  That will run the best ITs and tests but will probably take around 20 to 30 minutes, depending on your machine.

Initially I did not. But I read this and just ran it on my machine.
Everything built successfully using that -Psunny switch!

I put the link to the wrong PR but you figured it out :) Thanks!

I'm happy to do the leg work on this, but could someone (maybe @keith-turner?) help clue me in on how/why the WAL would be considered in an illegal state, and what could be done to remove/fix the illegal state?  The ones I am specifically experiencing are the `Saw consecutive COMPACTION_FINISH events` and `COMPACTION_FINISH (without preceding COMPACTION_START) is not followed by a successful minor compaction`.  Are exceptions the way to go with these or would logging be a better option since replaying the mutations is important? (I'm unfamiliar with the details of WAL recovery but am going over the code now).

I spoke to @keith-turner at length about this, and we (mostly Keith) came to the conclusion that these two errors *might* occur if you stop writing to one tablet, but continue writing mutations to another, and the logs roll over. In both cases, these exceptions could be thrown as a false positive, when there is no data to recover for that tablet, because the WAL containing the `COMPACTION_START` event could have been garbage collected.

Worse, this scenario may not be tested for, because our continuous ingest tests don't ever stop writing to a tablet.

The workaround would be to inspect the WALs and verify that there is no data for the tablet which produced the exception during recovery, and remove the entries in the affected tablet, and to repeat for each affected tablet. This is not ideal, but if somebody can verify that this is what is happening (it's still just speculation right now), we could proceed with a fix for 1.9.2. The good news is that there shouldn't be any data loss, if this is what is happening. It's just an error when there's no data necessary to recover.

Some possible fixes we discussed, if the issue can be verified:

1. Check that there are no data events in the WALs for that tablet, before throwing the exception.
2. Don't mark a WAL inactive prematurely, even if it has only a `COMPACTION_START` event with no data.

More investigation is needed to verify the problem, and possible fixes, though.

Thanks, @ctubbsii.  I'm about to start working on a tool to run through the recovery process outside of Accumulo to help me step through the affected log and get a clearer picture on what is happening during recovery.

Also, the error messages are confusing. Both of the error messages you pasted here are reporting something similar: a missing `COMPACTION_START` event. In the "consecutive" case, it's fine that the first `COMPACTION_FINISH` is without a corresponding `START`, so long as the the one that follows has a `START` (and it doesn't, hence the error). In the second "not followed by a successful minor compaction" case, it is just pointing out that there's a single `FINISH` all alone with a missing `START`.

Both error messages could be improved.

Yeah lol no worries I did one for another project (Fluo) so I'm broken in :)

Working through fixing the tablets on our cluster -- Regarding recovery, each tablet recovers the relevant mutations from the WAL, yes?  Once tablet recovery has settled down, swapping out a WAL file would only affect the tablets with these errors.  So if there are no mutations for the given extent, then it'd be safe to swap it out with an empty and then there wouldn't be any data loss (no mutations for the busted tablet and all the other tablets have already recovered).

As an aside, it'd be good to add the broken WAL in the error message.

@adamjshook Yes, each tablet should recover its own relevant mutations from the sorted WAL logs, which are created from the individual WAL files.

If there are no mutations for the given extent / tablet, then swapping out with an empty should be fine. Were you able to verify that the affected tablets had no relevant mutations in the WAL?

I'm trudging my way through them... There are 15 affected tablets and I've checked one so far and it doesn't have any mutations -- just a single `COMPACTION_FINISH` event.  Working my way through the tooling to make it a little easier to diagnose.
@ctubbsii  need anything else on this pr before merging?

Wait, spoke too soon.  I thought that loop in `findLastStartToFinish` was looping through mutations but that doesn't seem to be the case.  Within that loop there is only one `COMPACTION_FINISH` event, but if I remove the exception being thrown there are 80 mutations that need to be replayed.

One possible way to fix this is to make the tablet server keep all WALs newer than the oldest referenced.  So if a tserver has 4 closed WALs W1, W2, W3, W4 where W4 is the oldest and W1, W3 are referenced then W1,W2,W3 should be kept in zookeeper.  In this case W4 can safely be GCed, but not W2.

> Within that loop there is only one COMPACTION_FINISH event, but if I remove the exception being thrown there are 80 mutations that need to be replayed.

@adamjshook  do you know how the sequence numbers of those mutations compare to the sequence number of the COMPACTION_FINISH event?

For the one tablet that I have been working on, logging the error regarding `COMPACTION_FINISH` instead of throwing an exception. Four WALs total.

```
findLastStartToFinish
COMPACTION_FINISH tabletId: 390 seq: 1295
COMPACTION_FINISH (without preceding COMPACTION_START) is not followed by a successful minor compaction in log: 7721209c-727f-4cba-aadc-b9b8482224ac
playbackMutations numlogs: 4 tabletId: 390 recoverySeq: 0
MANY_MUTATIONS tabletId: 390 seq: 1295 size: 28
MANY_MUTATIONS tabletId: 390 seq: 1295 size: 26
MANY_MUTATIONS tabletId: 390 seq: 1295 size: 26
Finished recovery
KeyExtent 1;85766;8294 has 80 mutations
```

Related question (cc @joshelser) -- would the original bugs from 1.8.0+ be prevalent in the replication system?  From what I can tell they are strictly related to recovery and the replication system reads through the WAL serially looking for `MUTATION` and `MANY_MUTATIONS` events.

> From what I can tell they are strictly related to recovery and the replication system reads through the WAL serially looking for MUTATION and MANY_MUTATIONS events.

You're right here. I haven't done enough digging into the core-problem that was fixed, but I'd be surprised if it's an issue.
I am seeing some WAL and Replication ITs timeout, so the locking introduced in this PR may be causing a problem.

I thought of this while working on #538 and #541.  If something like this were added it would be nice to also add user level tools like mentioned in #535 to help users figure things out if these stateful checks trigger.

@keith-turner @ctubbsii Do you think it’d be safe for me to apply a patch on our end to temporarily remove the IllegalStateExceptions and roll with that? Or would we be better off waiting for some official patches? Thanks!
I would be hesitant to call anything "safe" until we've finished testing, but if you wanted to test, you could try  the patch in #541 and the related #540 (#539 may also fix another WAL bug).
Thanks, I'll get this out on our dev/stage systems and help out on the testing.

I added pausing to continuous ingest tests to reproduce this exception.  I ran 2 tests today using 1.9.1 and was able to reproduce this problem within an hour each time.  I am now running with Keith's patches to see if they fix this bug.  I will let everyone knows how this testing goes.
Testing went well. I did not see the exception/table problem occur overnight.  However, I would like to test some more.
WriteAheadLogIT timed out once on Jenkins, it was automatically run again and it passed.    I ran WriteAheadLogIT 6 or 7 times locally without issue.
This is stuck in the code added in #539

I think I know what is happening, a non-metadata tablet is holding its logLock while trying to write to a metadata tablet that is not online.  The metadata tablet loads, recovers, and then minor compacts.  After the metadata tablet minor compacts it attempts to do book keeping for WALs and this process tries to lock all other tablets logLocks.  This results in deadlock.

I ran WriteAheadLogIT and looked at the debug logs to see if this change was working as expected.  Saw the following which showed the set operations were working as expected.

```
2018-06-29 16:39:25,397 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs for memory compacted: 1<< 38577b31-28a0-46d8-9467-84d2952e1d17
2018-06-29 16:39:25,398 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs for memory compacted: 1<< 697f2016-6e73-454b-b550-1d882272c520
2018-06-29 16:39:25,398 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs for memory compacted: 1<< ad2640e2-001a-4835-b2a2-5bbcc9eeb374
2018-06-29 16:39:25,398 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs for current memory: 1<< 697f2016-6e73-454b-b550-1d882272c520
2018-06-29 16:39:25,398 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs to be destroyed: 1<< 38577b31-28a0-46d8-9467-84d2952e1d17
2018-06-29 16:39:25,398 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs to be destroyed: 1<< ad2640e2-001a-4835-b2a2-5bbcc9eeb374
```

I am going to rebase since there have been a lot of commits between @PircDef and I.

@EdColeman A few helpful things for using GitHub:

* There is no need to create an issue *and* a PR if you are creating them at the same time. GitHub PRs are their own issue. Sometimes it's useful to create an issue for future work.
* It is not necessary to close a PR and create a new one to change the branch. You can click the "Edit" button and select a different branch to do the PR against from the drop-down.
* When you use the form "ACCUMULO-NNN", it automatically links against the JIRA issue with that ID, and that JIRA issue (such as https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-551) may be completely unrelated. GitHub issues are mentioned using the pound syntax: #551
Do you know if a similar issue affects the 2.0 monitor?
The code for 2.0 has changed such that I do not see the same issue - but I'll need to dig deeper to find the actual display code - a quick look and it seems that milliseconds are being passed around.
@mikewalch I created the docs you suggested apache/accumulo-website#92

I just want to document my testing for this PR. I ran continuous ingest on a 10 node cluster. I shortened agitation for to only 1-2 min for tservers. I made the wal log max size about 2MB. I ran one ingest test with 9 ingesters and no pausing and several other ingest tests with 1 ingester and pausing every few minutes. After the tests had run over night, I stopped the ingesters and ran verify.

I was a bit uneasy with the unlimited thread pool, so I made the number of threads configurable again in 476db84.  It defaults to an unlimited threads pool, but if that causes problems there is a config option to limit the thread pool size.
@mikewalch By "ran verify", do you mean verifiy succeeded on both tables (assuming you ran CI against two tables to try to reproduce)?

I would think this original request is now OBE, since the bugs should no longer occur. We could always revisit the idea of creating additional tooling to assist manual recovery in a subsequent issue, if it's really necessary.

I am not sure  what to do this issue,  I would leave that to @adamjshook.   @ctubbsii the reason I asked you about removing the blocker label was because I saw you added it.

This is a duplicate of #547
Oops! nice catch, @ctubbsii

This could be a bit more general, with a scanner having a method like the following :

```
/**
 * Provides information to the server side scan dispatcher and prioritizer that may be used when making decisions about how to execute this scan on the server side.  However those server side classes may ignore these hints.
 */
void setExecutionHints(Map<String, String> hints){}
```

The hints would be made available on the server side via the ScanInfo interface.
@mikewalch Thanks for the feedback.  I am still working through some kinks but I will get to your suggestions as soon I have some more fixes up.
This is the proper fix to the issue described in #539.  Also this change may fix a deadlock introduced in #441 / #443.
This PR caused deadlock, which #545 attempted to fix.  However #545 also caused deadlock, which #559 ultimately fixed.  So #559 is really the fix for the problem described in this PR.

In order to test this a modification to Accumulo's data loss test suite was
made to pause ingest.  The problems in this issue are unlikely to be seen with
non-stop ingest.  To see these problems, the ability to randomly pause ingest was added in apache/accumulo-testing#15.

While looking into creating the release notes, I was getting confused trying to unravel and understand the #441 and #539 bugs fixes.  Looking back, I have it all sorted out in my mind now.  I am writing up a summary of my understanding in this comment.

For each tablet there are three different sets of active WALogs. While a WALog exist in anyone of these sets it must not be garbage collected.  The following are the three sets.

  1. WALogs related to the tablets active in memory map
  2. WAlogs related to the tablets inactive in memory map that is in the process of being minor compacted
  3. WAlogs related to a newly minor compacted file that is in the process of being added to the tablets row in the metadata table.

From Accumulo [1.8.0,1.9.0] only set 1 was consulted to determine what WALogs were active for a tablet.  In #443 the code was changed to also consider set 2, however this may have introduced a possible deadlock in the code.   So 1.9.1 consults sets 1 and 2, but may have a deadlock.  This PR also considers set 3 and fixes the deadlock.   So 1.9.2 consults sets 1,2,and 3 w/o having a deadlock.
I think this would be more beneficial in the older branches.  The changes we made in #560 remove this code.
Will need to cherry-pick back to 1.9. Changing the merge base to 1.9 will bring 1.9 all the way to master. I switched the merge-base for this PR back to master.
